Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Innovative ab initio symmetry-adapted no-core shell model for advancing fundamental physics and astrophysics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A team of researchers at Louisiana State University will address the significant computational challenges inherent to modeling the intricate dynamics of atomic nuclei, which are fundamental to a vast array of astrophysical phenomena. They will do so by employing the petascale resources of the Blue Waters Supercomputer. More specifically, the investigators will carry out large-scale computations of intermediate-mass nuclei from oxygen to argon, including exotic unstable isotopes that are the focus of current and next-generation rare isotope experimental facilities. Such nuclei are often found key to understanding processes in extreme environments, from stellar explosions to the interior of nuclear reactors. Reliable nuclear structure information provided by this research project will have impacts on basic research questions in astrophysics and neutrino physics, and will also have potential applications in areas like nuclear energy, thus contributing to the nation's energy infrastructure. Training in utilizing large-scale computational resources will be provided to, the next generation of physicists, and the team will expand the impact of their research by providing nuclear structure information of unprecedented accuracy and scope as a publicly available database for use by other scientists.

The LSU team's approach is to solve the Schrodinger equation for a many-body quantum system composed of protons and neutrons interacting via realistic interactions that are tied to the underlying quark/gluon considerations. The solution to this problem is achieved by finding eigenstates and eigenvalues of the nuclear Hamiltonian, which is computed in a physically relevant basis that capitalizes on exact and approximate symmetries of nuclei. The use of such symmetries is a unique feature of our model, one that coupled with the Blue Waters capabilities makes solutions feasible. Namely, the team will employ the symmetry-adapted no-core shell model approach implemented by a highly scalable computer code, dubbed "LSU3shell", that has already demonstrated good scalability and performance on the Blue Waters system. Calculations will provide nuclear properties of short-lived neutron-deficient and neutron-rich isotopes with little to no available experimental data that are expected to have a considerable impact on modeling X-ray burst observables, on triggering processes responsible for the synthesis of many of the heavy elements present in the universe, and on providing a stringent test of fundamental symmetries in nature and physics beyond the Standard model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Support of this proposal has enabled transformative research in low-energy nuclear science.  The combination of the ab initio symmetry-adapted no-core shell model (SA-NCSM) with the petascale computational power of the Blue Waters (BW) system has opened up an entire region of the periodic table, the intermediate-mass nuclei, to forefront research with ab initio theory that holds predictive capability. This has far-reaching implications beyond nuclear structure physics as well, namely, the outcomes of the project represent a first step toward achieving predictions for nuclei that are key to understanding nucleosynthesis and are of importance to neutrino research, and in turn, can help address two of the most fundamental questions of physics today: the origin of elements and if the neutrino is its own antiparticle. This research also involved graduate students and postdocs who have acquired and furthered their skills in the development of high performance computational physics software, laying the foundations for their careers in science and technology, as they get prepared to become the next-generation "petascale-smart" researchers.

 

The Blue Waters (BW) system enables us to achieve large-scale modeling of light and medium-mass nuclei, including short-lived nuclei not yet accessible to experiment but key to understanding astrophysical processes, which are the foci of current and next-generation rare isotope experimental facilities.  In particular, the LSU team has developed and optimized codes for the use of a symplectic basis, for one-body densities, as well as an initial implementation to treat three-nucleon interactions, including the work on code optimization and the use of GPU's, in close collaboration with the teams at Princeton U. (as part of a PAID award from U. of Illinois), Iowa State U., the Ohio State U., and Old Dominion U., along with Czech collaborators and the assistance of the BW project team.

 

New results are now available in the intermediate- and medium-mass nuclei, made possible by the combination of the ab initio SA-NCSM and the BW system. These include the first SA-NCSM calculations with chiral interactions, derived in the effective-field theory, of open-shell F, Ne, and Mg isotopes, as well as the short-lived Si-24. These nuclei along with other short-lived isotopes (that are difficult and often impossible to study experimentally) in the intermediate-mass region are key to further understanding phenomena such as X-ray burst nucleosynthesis. Specifically, we have calculated reaction rates for alpha capture on O-16 that use ab initio SA-NCSM wave functions for Ne-20 obtained in the challenging model space of 13 major shells (note that these solutions are feasible due to the ability of the SA-NCSM to trim the size of the model space to only the physically relevant basis states, e.g., down to tens of millions of basis states for the lowest 6+ state in Ne-20, as compared to the inaccessible full size of a trillion basis states). Reaction rates calculated from the SA-NCSM are found to have an effect on X-ray burst simulations.

 

We have also provided preliminary results for the very challenging nuclei of mass A=48, namely, first-principle simulations of Ca-48 and Ti-48 in the SA-NCSM are now feasible and are of importance to studies of neutrinoless double-beta decay. The goal is to reduce large uncertainties in the nuclear structure matrix elements, which will, in turn, allow one to determine from planned experiments if the neutrino is a Majorana or Dirac particle, which represents one of the most fundamental problems in physics today.

 

A work in progress focuses on another challenging problem in nuclear physics today: achieving an ab initio description of the so-called Hoyle state in C-12, the resulting state of the essential stellar triple-alpha process, key to modeling nucleosynthesis and stellar explosions. We have also calculated negative-parity states in C-12 and giant monopole and quadrupole resonances.  We have studied low-lying resonances in He-10 with impact on experimental techniques around the neutron-drip line that involve halo nuclei.

 

Some 16 refereed publications (including two invited reviews and two computer science/computational physics articles), 2 conference proceedings, and a chapter in a book, in addition to 10 invited lectures have been produced under this award over its two-year period.  It also resulted in 13 talks or poster presentations of 3 LSU undergraduate students, 2 REU undergraduate students (including a recipient of a CEU award at the DNP APS meeting in 2015), and 3 graduate students, as well as a presentation of a graduate student at the Blue Waters symposium in 2016. Members of the collaboration have also attended scientific meetings where advanced applications of high-performance computers were reviewed and best practices were discussed. We have acquired knowledge of best practices for applications of hybrid computing, MPI/OpenMP, to forefront computational problems in nuclear structure. We have passed this knowledge on to students and postdocs in our groups.
